A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.
The codomain of a function is the set that contains all potential output values, even if some of those values are not actually produced by any input in the domain.
Does the concept of a/an Set need to be defined for a definition of a/an Codomain to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a codomain explicitly mentions that it is a set containing all potential output values of a function. This implies that the concept of a set is integral to understanding what a codomain is, as it uses the idea of a collection of objects (outputs in this case) grouped together as an entity. Without the concept of a set, the notion of a codomain would lack a framework to describe how these outputs are collectively handled and defined. Therefore, the concept of a set is necessary to fully define and comprehend what a codomain is.
